supporting.text: Spider wasps, like all insects, have six legs, not eight.

attacks.text: Spider wasps, like all insects, have six legs, not eight.
Spider wasps are arachnids, not insects, and thus have eight legs.
Spider wasps are actually a type of wasp, which are insects with six legs.
Some species of spider wasps may have leg-like appendages that resemble additional legs.

supporting.text: The claim is incorrect because arachnids have eight legs, but spider wasps are insects, not arachnids.

attacks.text: The claim is incorrect because arachnids have eight legs, but spider wasps are insects, not arachnids.
Spider wasps are indeed insects, but the claim is about their leg count, not their classification.
All insects, including spider wasps, have six legs, not eight.
Some insects can lose legs due to injury, potentially appearing to have fewer than six legs.

supporting.text: Entomological studies confirm that all members of the order Hymenoptera, including spider wasps, have six legs.

attacks.text: Entomological studies confirm that all members of the order Hymenoptera, including spider wasps, have six legs.
Some spider wasps may exhibit mutations or injuries leading to an abnormal number of legs.
The claim may be referring to the spider wasp's prey, which are spiders and have eight legs.
Documented cases of leg mutations in Hymenoptera are extremely rare and not representative of the species.
The original claim specifically mentions 'spider wasps', not their prey.

supporting.text: The anatomical structure of spider wasps aligns with the standard insect body plan, which includes six legs.

attacks.text: The anatomical structure of spider wasps aligns with the standard insect body plan, which includes six legs.
Spider wasps are arachnids, not insects, and thus have eight legs.
Spider wasps belong to the family Pompilidae, which are indeed insects and have six legs.
Some people confuse spider wasps with spiders due to their name and appearance, leading to the misconception of eight legs.
